The frequency of severe weather events, such as hurricanes and wildfires, would decrease, leading to fewer natural disasters and increased safety for people and ecosystems.
Melting glaciers and ice caps would slow and eventually stop, preventing the catastrophic impacts of sea-level rise and ocean acidification on marine life.
Many coral reefs and other sensitive ecosystems, currently under threat due to warming ocean temperatures and acidification, would begin to recover.
The range and abundance of species in ecosystems would stabilize, allowing for a greater diversity of flora and fauna to exist.
The effects of droughts and water scarcity on global agriculture and human settlements would decrease, allowing for greater food security and economic growth.
